author: DAVID RYE
content:
Why was US Navy transporting 220,000 barrels of jet fuel in Stena Immaculate tanker?

One crew member is missing, presumed dead, and more than 30 people were rescued after a Portuguese cargo ship, the Solong, collided with an oil tanker in the North Sea.
The Stena Immaculate tanker was on a charter to the US Navy’s Military Sealift Command and was carrying around 220,000 barrels of jet fuel in segregated cargo tanks when the incident happened.
Transport Minister Mike Kane told the House of Commons that the Marine Accident Investigation Branch had been investigating at the crash scene.
But what do we know about the collision so far? What do we know about the ships and what they were carrying?
BFBS Forces News answers some of the key questions.

Continues at https://www.forcesnews.com/news/why-was-us-navy-transporting-220000-barrels-jet-fuel-stena-immaculate-tanker

[Again apologies for previous duplicates. These things happen when one passed 91 but that is life but it is no excuse, just a fact.]

author: D. Peter Boucher, Kt. SMOM, International Master Mariner (retd.)
content:
Mr. Roche since an investigation is underway with no information yet released I am somewhat mystified as to how you know the anchored tanker did not have an anchor watch. Also it is clear from the AIS plot that the “Solong” just ran right into an anchored vessel.
It will be interesting to find out what crews the vessels were manned as Ramadan is now being observed also Lent. In both observations food intake is limited; Ramadan is particularly difficult. Having served with observing crews we always kept a close eye on them for Watchstanding.

Good Watch.

author: Chris Roche
content:
The cause will be human error on the part of both vessels. The one at anchor should have had an anchor/radar watch. The oncoming ship should have had a lookout as there was dense fog and should also have had a radar watch. This is what we always did when I was at sea it is well that both ships had black boxes. The Portuguese ship is currently under tow away from the area the firesare largely out now.
Chris R
